cards.title: Victorian tintypes / Do you recognise the Margate family?
cards.rawTitle: Do you recognise the Margate family?

item.title: Do you recognise the Margate family?
item.trailText: A set of Victorian photographs shows the same family on holiday over a number of years. But who are the ‘Margate family’ – and what became of them?
item.standFirst: While preparing for a new exhibition on Victorian photography, the curators came across something unusual: a series of tintype photographs of the same British family on holiday, over a number of years. As time passes the boys get older and a sister arrives. But who are the ‘Margate family’ – and what became of them?

displayImages.caption:
The photographs of the ‘Margate family’ come from the collection of Bernard Howarth-Loomes, and it is thought they were bought as a set. Lettering on the small boy’s bucket in one of the images determined that the resort was Margate, in Kent. The identity of the family is a mystery – if you recognise them, let us know in the comments below

Photography: A Victorian Sensation is at the National Museums of Scotland 19 June-22 November
All photographs: Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The photographs of the ‘Margate family’ come from the collection of Bernard Howarth-Loomes, and it is thought they were bought as a set. Lettering on the small boy’s bucket in one of the images determined that the resort was Margate, in Kent. The identity of the family is a mystery – if you recognise them, let us know in the comments below

Photography: A Victorian Sensation is at the National Museums of Scotland 19 June-22 November
All photographs: Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library

displayImages.caption: Tintypes, or ferrotypes, were introduced by the Parisian scientist Adolphe-Alexandre Martin in 1853, and were popular with itinerant photographers - especially on the beach - as the shots were developed immediately. The finished photograph could be handed to the customer within minutes, and prices were seldom above sixpence (6d – about £2 today)
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tintypes, or ferrotypes, were introduced by the Parisian scientist Adolphe-Alexandre Martin in 1853, and were popular with itinerant photographers - especially on the beach - as the shots were developed immediately. The finished photograph could be handed to the customer within minutes, and prices were seldom above sixpence (6d – about £2 today)

displayImages.caption: Here the brothers pose on donkeys outside a ‘bathing machine’. Modest Victorians would change inside the machine, then be wheeled to the sea and deposited in the water without being seen in their swimming costume
displayImages.credit: Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.altText: A ferrotype of two small boys on donkeys outside a bathing hut
displayImages.cleanCaption: Here the brothers pose on donkeys outside a ‘bathing machine’. Modest Victorians would change inside the machine, then be wheeled to the sea and deposited in the water without being seen in their swimming costume

displayImages.caption: Subtle changes in the family’s outfits indicate different holidays. Here, the father isn’t wearing a bow tie and the smaller son is wearing a sailor top. The mother has a new summer hat
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.altText: Ferrotypes, or tintypes, introduced by Adolphe-Alexandre Martin in 1853
displayImages.cleanCaption: Subtle changes in the family’s outfits indicate different holidays. Here, the father isn’t wearing a bow tie and the smaller son is wearing a sailor top. The mother has a new summer hat

displayImages.caption: In this shot the boys are taller, and the father now wears a tie. The quality of the tintype, and the modest outfits of the day, makes it difficult to judge the weather or exact time of year. After the Bank Holidays Act of 1871, families would travel down the river Thames by steamer to Kent’s holiday resorts at Margate and Ramsgate
displayImages.credit: Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.altText: Two Boys With Buckets and Spades
displayImages.cleanCaption: In this shot the boys are taller, and the father now wears a tie. The quality of the tintype, and the modest outfits of the day, makes it difficult to judge the weather or exact time of year. After the Bank Holidays Act of 1871, families would travel down the river Thames by steamer to Kent’s holiday resorts at Margate and Ramsgate

displayImages.caption: Possibly later on the same day, the boys have taken their trousers off, rolled up their sleeves and have wet pantaloons from building sandcastles
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.cleanCaption: Possibly later on the same day, the boys have taken their trousers off, rolled up their sleeves and have wet pantaloons from building sandcastles

displayImages.caption: As the family grows older, they are joined by a younger sibling. We also notice the fashions change – the mother’s simple straw hat is replaced by something more formal
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.cleanCaption: As the family grows older, they are joined by a younger sibling. We also notice the fashions change – the mother’s simple straw hat is replaced by something more formal

displayImages.caption: Our first clue as to the identity of the photographer - W Colder. Tintype photography did not flip the image using a mirror like modern cameras do, so everything is shot in reverse.
displayImages.credit: Genevieve Hanson/Kodak Collection/National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library
displayImages.cleanCaption: Our first clue as to the identity of the photographer - W Colder. Tintype photography did not flip the image using a mirror like modern cameras do, so everything is shot in reverse.
